posts.title: Homotopy
posts.excerpt: Homological algebra初步, 对一些homotopy性质的讨论. Homology函子将homotopic的morphism映射到相同的morphism, 这是以后讨论homotopy需要用到的最根本的性质之一. 以及这个homotopy定义实在是抽象.
posts.text: Homological algebra初步, 对一些homotopy性质的讨论. Homology函子将homotopic的morphism映射到相同的morphism, 这是以后讨论homotopy需要用到的最根本的性质之一. 以及这个homotopy定义实在是抽象. Homotopy Definition 1. A homotopy h:f→gh:f\to gh:f→g between two maps f,g:A→Bf,g: A\to Bf,g:A→B is a family of morphisms hn:An→Bnh_{n}:A_{n}\to B_{n}hn​:An​→Bn​ s.t. the following diagram commutes and fn−gn=dn+1hn+hn−1dnf_{n}-g_{n}=d_{n+1}h_{n}+h_{n-1}d_{n}fn​−gn​=dn+1​hn​+hn−1​dn​ for all nnn. We write f≃gf\simeq gf≃g. We give some basic property of homotopy. Proposition 1. The homotopy relation is an equivalence. Proof Proof.For tansitivity: If f≃gf\simeq gf≃g, g≃hg\simeq hg≃h,fn−gn=dn+1sn+sn−1dnf_{n}-g_{n}=d_{n+1}s_{n}+s_{n-1}d_{n}fn​−gn​=dn+1​sn​+sn−1​dn​gn−hn=dn+1tn+tn−1dng_{n}-h_{n}=d_{n+1}t_{n}+t_{n-1}d_{n}gn​−hn​=dn+1​tn​+tn−1​dn​Sofn−gn=dn+1(sn+tn)+(sn−1+tn−1)dnf_{n}-g_{n}=d_{n+1}(s_{n}+t_{n})+(s_{n-1}+t_{n-1})d_{n}fn​−gn​=dn+1​(sn​+tn​)+(sn−1​+tn−1​)dn​ i.e. f≃hf\simeq hf≃h.For symmetric: If f≃gf\simeq gf≃g, $$f_{n}-g_{n}=d_{n+1}h_{n}+h_{n-1}d_{n}\Rightarrow g_{n}-f_{n}=d_{n+1}(-h_{n})+(-h_{n-1})d_{n}$$For reflectivity: Obvious. ◻ Proposition 2. Let f≃g:A→Bf\simeq g:A\to Bf≃g:A→B, f′≃g′:B→Cf'\simeq g':B\to Cf′≃g′:B→C, then f′f≃g′g:A→Cf'f\simeq g'g:A\to Cf′f≃g′g:A→C. Proof Proof. Let fn−gn=dn+1hn+hn−1dnf_{n}-g_{n}=d_{n+1}h_{n}+h_{n-1}d_{n}fn​−gn​=dn+1​hn​+hn−1​dn​ and fn′−gn′=dn+1hn′+hn−1′dnf'_{n}-g'_{n}=d_{n+1}h'_{n}+h'_{n-1}d_{n}fn′​−gn′​=dn+1​hn′​+hn−1′​dn​. Thengn′fn−gn′gn=gn′dn+1hn+gn′hn−1dn=dn+1(gn′hn)+(gn′hn−1)dng'_{n}f_{n}-g'_{n}g_{n}=g'_{n}d_{n+1}h_{n}+g'_{n}h_{n-1}d_{n}=d_{n+1}(g'_{n}h_{n})+(g'_{n}h_{n-1})d_{n}gn′​fn​−gn′​gn​=gn′​dn+1​hn​+gn′​hn−1​dn​=dn+1​(gn′​hn​)+(gn′​hn−1​)dn​fn′fn−gn′fn=dn+1hnfn−hn−1dnfn=dn+1(hnfn)+(hn−1fndn)f'_{n}f_{n}-g'_{n}f_{n}=d_{n+1}h_{n}f_{n}-h_{n-1}d_{n}f_{n}=d_{n+1}(h_{n}f_{n})+(h_{n-1}f_{n}d_{n})fn′​fn​−gn′​fn​=dn+1​hn​fn​−hn−1​dn​fn​=dn+1​(hn​fn​)+(hn−1​fn​dn​)Thus gn′fn≃gn′gng'_{n}f_{n}\simeq g'_{n}g_{n}gn′​fn​≃gn′​gn​ and fn′fn≃gn′fnf'_{n}f_{n}\simeq g'_{n}f_{n}fn′​fn​≃gn′​fn​, so fn′fn≃gn′gnf'_{n}f_{n}\simeq g'_{n}g_{n}fn′​fn​≃gn′​gn​. ◻ Proposition 3. Let F:Ch(A)→Ch(A)F:\mathrm{Ch}(\mathcal{A})\to \mathrm{Ch}(\mathcal{A})F:Ch(A)→Ch(A) be an addictive functor. If f≃g:A→Bf\simeq g:A\to Bf≃g:A→B, then Ff≃Fg:FA→FBFf\simeq Fg:FA\to FBFf≃Fg:FA→FB. Proof Proof. Let h:f→gh:f\to gh:f→g. Then we have$$\begin{aligned}Ff_{n}-Fg_{n}&=F(d_{n+1}h_{n}+h_{n-1}d_{n})\\&= F(d_{n+1})F(h_{n})+F(h_{n-1})F(d_{n})\end{aligned}$$So Ff≃FgFf\simeq FgFf≃Fg. ◻ Homotopy and homology functor The homotopic morphisms will induce the same morphism under homology functor H(−)H(-)H(−). Theorem 1. For f≃g:A→Bf\simeq g:A\to Bf≃g:A→B with h:f→gh:f\to gh:f→g, we have H(f)≃H(g)H(f)\simeq H(g)H(f)≃H(g). Proof Proof.$$\begin{aligned}\mathrm{Im}(f-g)&=(f-g)(\mathrm{Ker}d_{n})\\&=d_{n+1}h_{n}(\mathrm{Ker}d_{n})+h_{n-1}d_{n}(\mathrm{Ker}d_{n})\\&=d_{n+1}h_{n}(\mathrm{Ker}d_{n})\subset\mathrm{Im}d_{n+1}\end{aligned}$$So H(f−g)=0H(f-g)=0H(f−g)=0, i.e. H(f)=H(g)H(f)=H(g)H(f)=H(g). ◻ There’s an example f≄gf\not\simeq gf≃g but H(f)=H(g)H(f)=H(g)H(f)=H(g). Take the chain complex Let f0=id:Z→Zf_{0}=id:\mathbb{Z}\to \mathbb{Z}f0​=id:Z→Z and gn≡0g_{n}\equiv 0gn​≡0, we have Hn(f)=Hn(g)=0H_{n}(f)=H_{n}(g)=0Hn​(f)=Hn​(g)=0 since H0(A)=Z2H_{0}(A)=Z_{2}H0​(A)=Z2​ and H0(B)=ZH_{0}(B)=\mathbb{Z}H0​(B)=Z. However, f≄gf\not\simeq gf≃g, to see this, we tensor Z2Z_{2}Z2​ on AAA and BBB as Z\mathbb{Z}Z module. H0(A⊗Z2)≅Z2H_{0}(A\otimes Z_{2})\cong Z_{2}H0​(A⊗Z2​)≅Z2​ and H0(B⊗Z2)≅Z2H_{0}(B\otimes Z_{2})\cong Z_{2}H0​(B⊗Z2​)≅Z2​, H0(f⊗id)=1H_{0}(f\otimes id)=1H0​(f⊗id)=1 but H(g⊗Z2)=0H(g\otimes Z_{2})=0H(g⊗Z2​)=0. From Proposition 3 above, fff and ggg cannot be homotopic.

posts.text: Homological algebra初步的初步. Chain complex的定义以及一些性质. 再没有tikz-cd我要死了. Chain Complex Definition 1. A chain complex (A,d)(A,d)(A,d) in an addicitive category A\mathcal{A}A is a family of objects and morphisms: $$\cdots\xrightarrow{}A_{n+1}\xrightarrow{d_{n+1}}A_{n}\xrightarrow{d_{n}}A_{n-1}\xrightarrow{}\cdots$$ with di−1∘di=0d_{i-1}\circ d_{i}=0di−1​∘di​=0 for all i∈Zi\in\mathbb{Z}i∈Z. The family ddd as well as its components dnd_{n}dn​ is called the differential of boundary morphism. Definition 2. A morphism of complexes f:(A,dA)→(B,dB)f:(A,d^{A})\to (B,d^{B})f:(A,dA)→(B,dB) is a family of morphisms: fn:An→Bnf_{n}:A_{n}\to B_{n}fn​:An​→Bn​, n∈Zn\in \mathbb{Z}n∈Z s.t. the diagram commutes. To simplify the notation, we always write it as fdA=dBffd^{A}=d^{B}ffdA=dBf. The category of chain complex in A\mathcal{A}A is denoted Ch(A)\mathrm{Ch}(\mathcal{A})Ch(A). The full subcategory whose objects are of the form $$\cdots\xrightarrow{}A_{1}\xrightarrow{}A_{0}\xrightarrow{}0\xrightarrow{}\cdots$$ is denoted Ch≥0(A)\mathrm{Ch}_{\geq 0}(\mathcal{A})Ch≥0​(A). If A\mathcal{A}A is an addicitive category, it’s easy to verify Ch(A)\mathrm{Ch}(\mathcal{A})Ch(A) is an abelian category. Proposition 1. For morphism f:A→Bf:A\to Bf:A→B, fff is injective(resp. surjective) if and only if fn:An→Bnf_{n}:A_{n}\to B_{n}fn​:An​→Bn​ is injective(resp. surjective) for all nnn. Proof Proof. Obvious. ◻ Proposition 2. A→fB→gCA\xrightarrow{f}B\xrightarrow{g}CAf​Bg​C is exact if and only if for all nnn, An→fnBn→gnCnA_{n}\xrightarrow{f_{n}}B_{n}\xrightarrow{g_{n}}C_{n}An​fn​​Bn​gn​​Cn​ are exact. Proof Proof. Obvious. ◻ Homology Definition 3. Let AAA be a chain complex, the nnn-th homology group of AAA is defined to be Hn(A)=Kerdn/Imdn+1H_{n}(A)=\mathrm{Ker}d_{n} /\mathrm{Im}d_{n+1}Hn​(A)=Kerdn​/Imdn+1​. From the diagram we can derive H(fn):Hn(A)→Hn(B)H(f_{n}):H_{n}(A)\to H_{n}(B)H(fn​):Hn​(A)→Hn​(B) by fn:KerdnA→KerdnBf_{n}:\mathrm{Ker}d_{n}^{A}\to \mathrm{Ker}d_{n}^{B}fn​:KerdnA​→KerdnB​ and fn:Imdn+1A→Imdn+1Bf_{n}:\mathrm{Im}d_{n+1}^{A}\to \mathrm{Im}d_{n+1}^{B}fn​:Imdn+1A​→Imdn+1B​ and the universal property of quotient. So we see actually H(−)H(-)H(−) is a functor Hn(−):Ch(A)→AH_{n}(-):\mathrm{Ch}(\mathcal{A})\to \mathcal{A}Hn​(−):Ch(A)→A. Often, in particular in applications to topology, elements of chain complex AnA_{n}An​ are called nnn-chains; elements of Kerdn\mathrm{Ker}d_{n}Kerdn​ are called nnn-cycles and Kerdn\mathrm{Ker}d_{n}Kerdn​ is written Zn=Zn(A)Z_n = Z_n(A)Zn​=Zn​(A); elements of Imdn+1\mathrm{Im}d_{n+1}Imdn+1​ are called nnn-boundaries and Imdn+1\mathrm{Im}d_{n+1}Imdn+1​ is written Bn=Bn(A)B_n = B_n(A)Bn​=Bn​(A). Two nnn-cycles which determine the same element in Hn(A)H_n(A)Hn​(A) are called homologous. The element of Hn(A)H_n(A)Hn​(A) determined by the nnn-cycle ccc is called the homology class of ccc, and is denoted by [c][c][c]. Cochain Complex Definition 4. A chain complex (A,d)(A,d)(A,d) in an addicitive category A\mathcal{A}A is a family of objects and morphisms: ⋯→An−1→dn−1An→dnAn+1→⋯\cdots\xrightarrow{}A^{n-1}\xrightarrow{d_{n-1}}A^{n}\xrightarrow{d^{n}}A^{n+1}\xrightarrow{}\cdots ⋯​An−1dn−1​​Andn​An+1​⋯ with di∘di+1=0d^{i}\circ d^{i+1}=0di∘di+1=0 for all i∈Zi\in\mathbb{Z}i∈Z. The morphisms and cohomology functor is defined similarly. For a chain complex A=(An,dnA)A=(A_{n},d_{n}^{A})A=(An​,dnA​), we can obtain a cochain complex B=(Bn,dBn)B=(B^{n},d^{n}_{B})B=(Bn,dBn​) by setting Bn=A−nB^{n}=A_{-n}Bn=A−n​ and dBn=d−nAd^{n}_{B}=d_{-n}^{A}dBn​=d−nA​. Long Exact Sequence Theorem Lemma 1 (Snake lemma). Let AAA be an abelian category. Let be a commutative diagram with exact rows. There exists a unique morphism δ:Kerγ→Cokerα\delta:\mathrm{Ker}\gamma\to \mathrm{Coker}\alphaδ:Kerγ→Cokerα s.t. the diagram commutes, where π′\pi'π′, π\piπ are the canonical projections and τ\tauτ, τ′\tau'τ′ are the canonical injections. If fff is injective the so is f′f'f′, and if lll is surjective then so is l′l'l′. Proof Proof. See Stack Project 010Hhttps://stacks.math.columbia.edu/tag/010H. ◻ Theorem 1 (Long exact seq.). Given a short exact seq. of chain complexes 0→A→fB→gC→00\xrightarrow{}A\xrightarrow{f}B\xrightarrow{g}C\xrightarrow{}00​Af​Bg​C​0, there are connecting morphisms δn:Hn(C)→Hn−1(A)\delta_{n}:H_{n}(C)\to H_{n-1}(A)δn​:Hn​(C)→Hn−1​(A) s.t. $$\cdots\xrightarrow{} H_{n}(A)\xrightarrow{}H_{n}(B)\xrightarrow{}H_{n}( C)\xrightarrow{\delta_{n}}H_{n-1}(A)\xrightarrow{}H_{n-1}(B)\xrightarrow{}H_{n-1}( C)\xrightarrow{}\cdots$$ is an exact sequence. Proof Proof. Consider exact sequence:0→An→fnBn→gnCn→00\xrightarrow{}A_{n}\xrightarrow{f_{n}}B_{n}\xrightarrow{g_{n}}C_{n}\xrightarrow{}0 0​An​fn​​Bn​gn​​Cn​​0Since fnf_{n}fn​ takes Imdn+1A\mathrm{Im}d_{n+1}^{A}Imdn+1A​ to Imdn+1B\mathrm{Im}d_{n+1}^{B}Imdn+1B​, gng_{n}gn​ takes Imdn+1B\mathrm{Im}d_{n+1}^{B}Imdn+1B​ to Imdn+1C\mathrm{Im}d_{n+1}^{ C}Imdn+1C​, we have the sequence $$A_{n} /\mathrm{Im}d_{n+1}^{A}\xrightarrow{\bar{f_{n}}} B_{n} /\mathrm{Im}d_{n+1}^{B}\xrightarrow{\bar{g_{n}}}C_{n} /\mathrm{Im}d_{n+1}^{ C}$$ exact. Since gng_{n}gn​ surjective, gnˉ\bar{g_{n}}gn​ˉ​ is also surjective. We have the exact sequence $$A_{n} /\mathrm{Im}d_{n+1}^{A}\xrightarrow{\bar{f_{n}}} B_{n} /\mathrm{Im}d_{n+1}^{B}\xrightarrow{\bar{g_{n}}}C_{n} /\mathrm{Im}d_{n+1}^{ C}\xrightarrow{}0$$Similarly,0→KerdnA→KerdnB→KerdnC0\xrightarrow{}\mathrm{Ker}d_{n}^{A}\xrightarrow{}\mathrm{Ker}d_{n}^{B}\xrightarrow{}\mathrm{Ker}d_{n}^{C}0​KerdnA​​KerdnB​​KerdnC​is an exact sequence.Since dn∘dn+1=0d_{n}\circ d_{n+1}=0dn​∘dn+1​=0, we have dn+1Ad_{n+1}^{A}dn+1A​ restric to An/Imdn+1AA_{n} /\mathrm{Im}d_{n+1}^{A}An​/Imdn+1A​ to KerdnA\mathrm{Ker}d_{n}^{A}KerdnA​, we ge the commutative diagram:Ker(dnA:An/Imdn+1A→KerdnA)=Hn(A)\mathrm{Ker}(d_{n}^{A}:A_{n} /\mathrm{Im}d_{n+1}^{A}\to \mathrm{Ker}d_{n}^{A})=H_{n}(A)Ker(dnA​:An​/Imdn+1A​→KerdnA​)=Hn​(A) and Coker(dnA:An/Imdn+1A→KerdnA)=Hn−1(A)\mathrm{Coker}(d_{n}^{A}:A_{n} /\mathrm{Im}d_{n+1}^{A}\to \mathrm{Ker}d_{n}^{A})=H_{n-1}(A)Coker(dnA​:An​/Imdn+1A​→KerdnA​)=Hn−1​(A), by snake lemma, it induces $$\cdots\xrightarrow{} H_{n}(A)\xrightarrow{}H_{n}(B)\xrightarrow{}H_{n}( C)\xrightarrow{\delta_{n}}H_{n-1}(A)\xrightarrow{}H_{n-1}(B)\xrightarrow{}H_{n-1}( C)\xrightarrow{}\cdots$$ ◻ Similarly result for cochain. For any [c]∈Hn(C)[c]\in H_{n}(C)[c]∈Hn​(C), ∃b∈Bn\exists b\in B_{n}∃b∈Bn​ s.t. gn(b)=cg_{n}(b)=cgn​(b)=c. Then gn−1(dnB(b))=dnC(gn(b))g_{n-1}(d_{n}^{B}(b))=d_{n}^{C}(g_{n}(b))gn−1​(dnB​(b))=dnC​(gn​(b)). ∃a∈An−1\exists a\in A_{n-1}∃a∈An−1​ with fn−1(a)=dnB(b)f_{n-1}(a)=d_{n}^{B}(b)fn−1​(a)=dnB​(b). posts.title: An example of direct sum but not split exact sequence
posts.excerpt: 一个含有direct sum的short exact sequence但不是split short exact sequence的例子.
posts.text: 一个含有direct sum的short exact sequence但不是split short exact sequence的例子. Recall the definition of split exact sequence We say a short exact sequence split iff. it is isomorphic to the exact sequence 0→A→fA⊕B→gB→00\xrightarrow{} A\xrightarrow{f} A\oplus B \xrightarrow{g} B\xrightarrow{}0 0​Af​A⊕Bg​B​0 where fff is the inclusion of the first component and ggg is the projection onto the second component. 注意到split exact seq 在定义里要求fff 和ggg 分别是到A⊕BA\oplus BA⊕B的每一个component, 是否有例子使得一般的short exact seq s.t. 0→A→fA⊕B→gB→00\xrightarrow{} A\xrightarrow{f} A\oplus B \xrightarrow{g} B\xrightarrow{}00​Af​A⊕Bg​B​0 但是不是exact seq? 答案是Yes. Example of non split exact sequence Consider the short exact sequence 0→Z/2Z→fZ/4Z→gZ/2Z→00\xrightarrow{} \mathbb{Z}/2\mathbb{Z}\xrightarrow{f} \mathbb{Z}/4\mathbb{Z} \xrightarrow{g} \mathbb{Z}/2\mathbb{Z}\xrightarrow{}0 0​Z/2Zf​Z/4Zg​Z/2Z​0 where fff is the inclusion of the subgroup generated by 2, so f(1)=2f(1) = 2f(1)=2, and ggg is the quotient onto that subgroup, meaning g(1)=1g(1) = 1g(1)=1. This is not a split short exact sequence(obviously). Consider M⨁N(Z/2Z⊕Z/4Z)M\bigoplus\limits_{\mathbb{N}}(\mathbb{Z}/2\mathbb{Z}\oplus\mathbb{Z}/4\mathbb{Z})MN⨁​(Z/2Z⊕Z/4Z). Thus the exact seq 0→Z/2Z→hZ/4Z⊕M→iZ/2Z⊕M→00\xrightarrow{} \mathbb{Z}/2\mathbb{Z}\xrightarrow{h} \mathbb{Z}/4\mathbb{Z}\oplus M \xrightarrow{i} \mathbb{Z}/2\mathbb{Z}\oplus M\xrightarrow{}0 0​Z/2Zh​Z/4Z⊕Mi​Z/2Z⊕M​0 with h(a)=(f(a),0)h(a) = (f(a), 0)h(a)=(f(a),0) and t(a,m)=(g(a),m)t(a, m) = (g(a), m)t(a,m)=(g(a),m) is exact. Z/4Z⊕M\mathbb{Z}/4\mathbb{Z}\oplus MZ/4Z⊕M is isomorphic to (Z/2Z)⊕(Z/2Z⊕M)(\mathbb{Z}/2\mathbb{Z})\oplus(\mathbb{Z}/2\mathbb{Z}\oplus M)(Z/2Z)⊕(Z/2Z⊕M). However, this is not a split exact seq since 0→Z/2Z→hZ/4Z⊕M→iZ/2Z⊕M→00\xrightarrow{} \mathbb{Z}/2\mathbb{Z}\xrightarrow{h} \mathbb{Z}/4\mathbb{Z}\oplus M \xrightarrow{i} \mathbb{Z}/2\mathbb{Z}\oplus M\xrightarrow{}0 0​Z/2Zh​Z/4Z⊕Mi​Z/2Z⊕M​0 will give a exact seq $$0\xrightarrow{} \mathbb{Z}/2\mathbb{Z}\xrightarrow{f} \mathbb{Z}/4\mathbb{Z} \xrightarrow{g} \mathbb{Z}/2\mathbb{Z}\xrightarrow{}0$$ which is not split exact.
